title: Observability Data Explosion
context: Teams adopt observability platforms (Datadog, New Relic, Splunk) to understand their distributed systems. The pitch: instrument everything, collect all the data, and you'll be able to debug any issue. So they do. Every service emits metrics, traces, and logs. The data volume explodes. The observability bill becomes one of the largest line items in the infrastructure budget — sometimes exceeding the cost of the infrastructure being observed. And despite all this data, teams still can't find the needle in the haystack when production breaks.
hypothesis: More observability data means better debugging and faster incident resolution.

chain.root: Instrument everything and collect all observability data

effects.label: Data volume and cost grow exponentially

children.label: Every new service, endpoint, and metric adds to the bill
Log volume grows 30-50% annually without intervention
Observability vendor pricing designed to scale with data — not with value

effects.label: More data doesn't mean better insights

children.label: Engineers spend more time querying dashboards than fixing issues
Too many metrics — nobody knows which ones matter
Dashboard sprawl: 50-200 dashboards, most never viewed

effects.label: Vendor lock-in through proprietary query languages and integrations
effects.impact: Migration cost: months of engineering time

children.label: Custom dashboards, alerts, and queries tied to vendor-specific syntax
Switching vendors means rebuilding all observability from scratch
Vendor raises prices knowing you can't easily leave
A developer adds a user_id tag to a metric — bill doubles overnight
Cardinality limits force teams to drop useful dimensions

impact.metric: Observability cost as % of infra spend

dontIf: Your observability bill exceeds 20% of your infrastructure cost
Your team has more dashboards than they can review in a week
ifYouMust: Define SLOs first, then instrument only what's needed to measure them
Implement sampling for high-volume traces and logs — you don't need 100% of everything
Set cardinality budgets and enforce them in CI
Audit dashboards and alerts quarterly — delete what nobody uses

alternatives.name: OpenTelemetry + open-source backends
alternatives.note: Vendor-neutral instrumentation with Grafana/Prometheus/Jaeger — control your data and costs

alternatives.name: SLO-driven observability
alternatives.note: Instrument for SLO measurement, not for 'collect everything' — focused and cost-effective

alternatives.name: Adaptive sampling
alternatives.note: Sample more during incidents, less during normal operation — right data at the right time
